question.title: Jackson deserializing - how to only deserialize annotated properties
question.body:
I have an application in which we need to send data back and forth via JSON and then map that to various objects in our application. I was able to configure it so that Jackson will only serialize properties with annotations, but I cannot seem to do the same thing for deserializing. The classes in question have extra fields that are not in the JSON. I am currently using Jackson 2.54 (yes, I know, it's old), but I can possibly upgrade to the latest version if I get approval from my superiors.

public class Person extends BaseClass {
    @JsonProperty("id")
    private String id;

    @JsonProperty("Email")
    private Email email;

    @JsonProperty("Name")
    private PersonNm name;

    private EndDt endDt;

    // Getters and setters for all of the above
}

As you can see, I have three properties marked with JsonProperty (and the setters and getters are marked as JsonSetter and JsonGetter respectively), but I have an extra property, "endDt". This property will never appear in the JSON, as it is to be used later. However, it still has two constructors:

public void setEndDt(Date val) {
    if (endDt == null)
        endDt = new EndDt();
    endDt.setValue(val);
}

public void setEndDt(EndDt val) {
    this.endDt = endDt;
}

The following JSON is sent in:

"Person": {
    "id": "1",
    "Email": {
        "value": "email@email.com"
    },
    "Name": {
        "value": "Bob Smith"
    }
}

Again, endDt is not there at all. But I am still getting the exception com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.exc.InvalidDefinitionException: Conflicting setter definitions for property "endDt": com.program.company.Person#setEndDt(com.program.company.EndDt) vs com.program.company.Person#setEndDt(java.util.Date).

I know that I could just use JsonIgnore, but there are multiple properties throughout many classes and it would be far easier to just have the deserializer ignore everything that isn't marked as "JsonProperty." I have my ObjectMapper configured as such:

ObjectMapper mapper = new ObjectMapper();
mapper.enable(DeserializationFeature.ACCEPT_SINGLE_VALUE_AS_ARRAY);
mapper.disable(DeserializationFeature.FAIL_ON_UNKNOWN_PROPERTIES);
mapper.disable(SerializationFeature.WRITE_DATES_AS_TIMESTAMPS);
mapper.disable(DeserializationFeature.FAIL_ON_INVALID_SUBTYPE);
mapper.disable(MapperFeature.AUTO_DETECT_SETTERS,
                MapperFeature.AUTO_DETECT_FIELDS,
                MapperFeature.AUTO_DETECT_CREATORS,
                MapperFeature.AUTO_DETECT_GETTERS,
                MapperFeature.AUTO_DETECT_IS_GETTERS);

So my question is, despite the existence of JsonIgnore, is there anything more convenient, a property I could set to just ignore all of the non-annotated fields?
